title: 112_hr3357
content: The Act may be cited as the "Child Marriage Violates the Human Rights of Girls Act of 2011". The findings are also included in the Act. Child marriage, also known as forced or early marriage, deprives girls of their human rights. It violates the Universal Declaration of Human Rights by not ensuring free and full consent. An estimated 60 million girls in developing countries were married before 18, with projections of 100 million more in the next decade. Child marriage has negative effects on girls' health, including increased risk of maternal death, obstetric fistula, sexually transmitted diseases, and infant mortality. Factors perpetuating child marriage include poverty, lack of educational opportunities, parental concerns, the dowry system, and the devaluation of girls. Girls' schooling, safe community spaces, and skills building programs for out-of-school girls are effective strategies to prevent child marriage and empower girls by addressing poverty, low status, and harmful norms. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton emphasizes that ending child marriage is crucial for achieving goals like primary education, improved health, and sustainable economic development for girls. Child marriage is defined as the marriage of a girl or boy below the minimum age for marriage in their country or under 18 if no such law exists. Congress acknowledges the importance of ending child marriage for achieving goals like education and economic development for girls. The sense of Congress is that child marriage is a violation of human rights and should be a foreign policy goal of the United States. Child marriage undermines investments in foreign assistance for education, health, and poverty reduction. Educational and economic opportunities for girls and women are crucial for achieving global health and development objectives, including HIV/AIDS prevention. The Secretary of State and relevant agencies must collect data on child marriage in countries receiving US assistance, including impact on development goals. Countries listed include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Burkina Faso, and others. Countries listed for data collection on child marriage impact include Republic, Chad, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, the Dominican Republic, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Guinea, Honduras, India, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. The Department of State's country reports on human rights practices are detailed in Section 6. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require a report on child marriage prevalence and foreign assistance in specific countries including Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, and others. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to require a report on child marriage prevalence and foreign assistance in specific countries including Mozambique, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. The term 'child marriage' is defined as the marriage of a girl or boy below the minimum age for marriage stipulated by law or under 18 if no such law exists in the country of residence. The report must include a description of the status of child marriage in each country and the amount of US foreign assistance used to prevent child marriage. The countries listed in paragraph (2) include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Dominican Republic, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Guinea, Honduras, India, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Nepal, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. The term 'child marriage' in paragraph (3) refers to the marriage of a girl or boy below the minimum age for marriage as stipulated by law or under 18 if no such law exists in their country of residence.
